div3.head: To correspondents.
div3.p:
We continue to receive an immense number of communications from every accessible quarter of the State.
The labor of revising them is very heavy, and our correspondents must be patient.
Those which are not really important we are compelled to omit altogether.
We cannot publish communications written on both sides of the paper.

div3.head: Notice to our Subscribers.
div3.p:
Subscribers to the Dispatch will observe the Cross make on their papers when their subscriptions are about to expire.
Those who wish to renew will forward the amount, or the papers will be stopped at the close of the term for which they have paid.

div3.head: Send us the News.
div3.p:
Our friends at the various camps and places of rendezvous and elsewhere, will confer a favor by sending to us any interesting intelligence, at the earliest practicable moment, for publication.
We desire to keep our readers informed in regard to everything that transpires, and will pay an adequate compensation for important news.

We were led into an unintentioal error in speaking of Mr. Moses, of Charleston, as attached to the Charleston Mercury. Mr. Moses has himself called upon us to correct the mistake.
He was formerly in the office of the Charleston Evening News, and is at present resident at that somewhat celebrated resort, Manassas Station.
Mr. Wm. A. Courtenay, of the business department of the Charleston Mercury, is now in this city, making arrangements to establish an agency for the regular sale of that excellent newspaper.

div3.head: War Panics and panic-makers.
div3.p:
There is a law upon the statute books of Virginia against false rumors in time of war. It is to be found in Henning. It is an old law, and still, we presume, in force; for it has never been and never ought to be repealed It denounces a heavy penalty against the disseminators of false intelligence.
The penalty could not well be too heavy.
The man who catches up an idle rumor on the wing, and is coward or fool enough to mount horse and gallop through the country "on the foaming and panting steed," spreading and magnifying the story, ought to be shot down as he flies.
Even if the rumor be true, that is not the way to treat it. It should be communicated quietly to the authorities, and these should take such discreet measures as at once to guard against the threatening danger, and to secure the composure of the community.
Panic often does more damage than an enemy.
It is infinitely more demoralizing; it is frequently more destructive.
In every community there are panic-makers by nature, who can't help getting frightened, and frightening everybody else, on the slightest provocation.
One of these panic-makers is worse than a squadron of the enemy's dragoons.
They will frighten more men out of the field than the dragoons could possibly disperse They will throw more old women into hysterics, they will cause more rushing to and fro of men, women, and boys, more slamming of doors, more breaking of windows, more petty accidents, and more universal destruction than an enemy.
A real enemy can travel but a few miles a day, and can cover but a small belt of country; but panic spreads like a circle in the water, embracing the whole surface of the country, and traveling as many miles in a day as an enemy can travel in a fortnight.

The old law against the bearers of false rumors and the manufacturers of panic, was wise and needful.
It ought to be revived and enforced.
It would prove a wonderful corrective against the recurrence of these demoralizing, distracting, and often ridiculous concomitants of war. But there is another remedy for them which should not be neglected.
It is the free and prompt circulation of correct intelligence in regard to the movements of the public enemy.
It is well that the Government in very critical emergencies should have control of telegraphs and other agencies of information, but if Government withholds the advices it receives, and at the same time lays the ordinary channels of news under embargo, they at once surrender the community to the dominion of rumor and the remorseless sway of panic.
It is all a mistake, too, in public officers to publish only good news and with hold what is bad. Bad news travels in the atmosphere, and magnifies as it travels.
The truth of bad news is less hurtful than exaggerations of it; and, as a measure of prudence, it is best to let the people have it. The more suspicion of the people that Government is not dealing fairly with them creates distrust, and prepares the public mind for panic and stampede.

But it is only in very critical emergencies that any official interference should be ventured with the ordinary transmission of news.
The press is the "fourth estate" of the present age. The community are accustomed to look to the press for early intelligence, and to hold it responsible for its accuracy.
The press has infinitely more at stake in its publication of news than any officer of Government can have.
It has to endure the wrath of public opinion if it abuse its powers of disseminating intelligence, by putting forth that which is false and which leads to injurious consequences.
At the same time, it has the strongest possible incentives to industry and fidelity in its avocation, those of pecuniary reward and prosperity.
It gains money by publishing correct news; it loses it by publishing spurious.
This is the best of all guarantee on this subject.
It is better than the censorship of the Government.
It is better than a monopoly by Government officers of all authenticated intelligence.

We make these remarks in no spirit of criticism and cavil.
We are willing that the legitimate province of the press shall be trenched upon in times of danger; but we take the liberty of expressing the deliberate judgment that, unless the public emergency be very critical, intelligence should be free to the press and the press free to lay it before the public.

The public is never a coward when it is not treated as a coward.
It can stand any amount of truth in the form of war intelligence; but if the truth is withheld, then its composure, reason, and manhood, is readily upset by idle rumor.
The last ten days have been fruitful of evil and even ridiculous results consequent upon letting rumor loose upon the public mind.
Public curiosity in war times, like Nature, abhors a vacuum.
It must be satisfied by news of some sort.
It truth is withheld, then in rushes rumor with her thousand false tongues, of which she is sure to make busy and hurtful use.

div3.head: Descendants of Gen. Greene.
div3.p:
The Commander-in-Chief of the Southern Army in the Revolution has now three great.
grandsons in the service of the South, two in Virginia and one in Georgia, to which latter State they all belong.
Gen. Greene was one of the most able Generals and true patriots of the times that tried men's souls, and we rejoice to see that his gallant and generous blood still flows through worthy channels.

div3.head: A Christian Association.
div3.p:
We have never been of those who could see logic or justice in imputing to religion the faults and the sins of its disciples.
We should as soon think of doubting the glory of the sun when its beams are intercepted by a fog, or question its life and health-giving influences, because malaria and snakes come forth at its bidding, as deny the Divine origin of Christianity because the best of its disciples are frail and imperfect men, and some of them deliberate hypocrites.
Indeed, this fact, as well as the general corruption of mankind, only confirm the Bible account of human nature, which represents it as desperately wicked, and which gives us instances of the best characters sometimes yielding to temptation.
But the same book certainly recognizes a class of deliberate pretenders and hypocrites, and tells us that we may know men by their fruits, and describes these fruits in the Christian as peace, charity, forbearance, long suffering, &c., whilst in the opposite they are hatred, variance, wrath, emulation, strife, &c., of which we are told that they who do such things cannot inherit the kingdom of God. Many graces are recounted in the Christian system, but we are told that Charity, or Love, is the greatest of all. "And now abideth Faith, Hope and Charity; but the greatest of these is Charity." It is, indeed, the great Godlike grace, for it was the Charity or Love of God to man which led to the Divine Sacrifice of His Son, and lies at the foundation of the whole Christian system.
And of all the virtues which that system enjoins, Forgiveness is the greatest.--Many virtues does it require,--humility, honesty, chastity, truth; but the forgiveness of enemies is prominent above them all, and is made the indispensable condition of man's forgiveness by God. We can conceive of a Christian falling into great sin, and even denying his master, like Peter; but it is impossible to conceive of any Christian man deliberately cultivating hatred towards another man, and especially towards another Christian.
These remarks are made to show that, in what we have to say of the Young Men's Christian Associations of the North, we consider ourselves as speaking not of Christians, but of wicked pretenders to that holy name, as their own fruits do manifest.

We are not, however, as much surprised as others may be at the article which we annex from the Elmira (N. Y.) Daily Press, and which has been put in our possession by an esteemed friend of the Richmond Christian Association.
The spirit of Puritanism was always a spirit of hate.
From the first Roundhead to the last, there never was one drop of the milk of human kindnsss or Christian charity in the heart.
We don't care where the thing is found, in Europe or America, nor in what age it lifts its head, it is always and everywhere full to the brim of envy, hatred, malice, and all uncharitableness.
It would rather "rule in hell than serve in Heaven," and therefore it left England for Holland, under the plea of persecution; therefore it left Holland, under the pretence that the Dutch were too wicked to be its companions; therefore it persecuted to the death men of every religion in America, and therefore it is now trying to crush out slavery and the descendants of the Cavaliers in the South.
The great, distinguishing, indispensable grace of charity was always as much lessened in the Puritan system as it was exalted in the Gospel, and whatever virtues have been ascribed by its adversaries to the Puritan character, the most fulsome and audacious of their panegyrists never yet claimed for them much love for anybody but themselves, or any forgiveness whatever for their enemies.
Hence, when the so-called Young Men's Christian Associations of the North have from the first hounded on this war in the spirit of incarnate fiends, we have taken it as the precise display which Puritanism might have been expected to make under the circumstances.
Not six months ago the same men looked as if "butter would not melt in their mouths;" they talked so low and sweet, and had such a sanctified smile, and went about with such a holy smirk, and had so much the appearance of rehearsing the parts of Christian, Faithful and Hopeful, in "Bunyan's Pilgrim's Progress," that we never met one of them in a lonely place without thanking Heaven that we had nothing in our pockets to be picked, and that, so far as we were aware of, nothing could be gained to anybody by cutting our throat.
Having said thus much, we introduce to our readers, as quite natural, and just what might have been expected, the following article from the Elmira Press, which we have not leisure to comment upon further at this time.
The paper was sent in an envelope, directed--"Corresponding Secretary Young Men's Christian Association, Richmond, Va. Care General Butler, Fortress Monroe.
General, please send along.
" Why didn't they ask that inebriated fellow-disciple to bring it himself?
Presentation of Swords by the Y. M. C. A. To Lieut. Wilkinson and Ensign Benedict.

The presentation took place on Friday evening, and was made the occasion of a pleasant re-union for the members of the Association and their friends.
A number of the Elmira Volunteers were present.
The room was filled to its utmost capacity, and a large representation of the soldiery filled the entrance and adjoining hall.
A familiar quotation from Halleck's "Marco Bozarris," the letters formed of evergreens, was placed prominently upon a wall of the room :

"Strike!
for your altars and your fires;
Strike! for the green graves of your sires,
God--and your native land."

The swords and scabbards were laid at the head of the reading table, and near by were arranged the seats to be occupied by the Vice-President, Prof. M. S. Converse, and the recipients of the presentation.
On the scabbard of each was engraved the name of the recipient and donors.
The presentation ceremonies were then opened by prayer by the Rev. J. L. Riggs. --The audience, led by Miss Sarah Brement upon the Melodeon, then sang "America. "

Immediately after, Prof. Converse arose and made the presentation speech.
He was aware that the general idea existed, that the work of a Christian Association was a peaceful one, and least of all that they had to do with weapons of a carnal warfare, but there were crises in the Union of moral and political affairs that required us to buckle on other armor than the one of faith, and when that event came he knew that the members of the Association would show themselves brave and courageous in the use of physical, as they have done with moral, weapons, while seeking the welfare, highest good, and enlightenment of their fellow-men.
To use such mercifully and righteously, he was sure the Association could commit the trust to no better hands than the representatives before them this evening;--at the same time presenting the swords to each, Lieutenant Wilkinson and Ensign Benedict.

Lieut. Wilkinson in reply said, that little did he think a short time ago that he should be occupying his present position.
And the thoughts which clustered in his mind to-night were sad ones.
it was hard parting with the Association, for to its influence, and the parting counsels and benediction of a mother, now a saint in Heaven, he owed all he was or hoped to be. The Bible, her last gift, should be ever his guide on the battle-field or in the camp; and palsied be his right arm and still his heart, if he put to disgraceful use the sword, for the gift of which his heart was too full of thanks to express.

Ensign Benedict thanked the Association for their precious gift.
He felt that there would be abundant occasion for its use. The war upon which we have entered, contrary to the expectations of many, he believed would be a long and desperate one.
He would promise that, whatever might be the results, his sword should never be drawn except for justice and right, and should never be put to a shameful use.

Prof Converse then, with humorous comment thereupon, read a circular from Richmond, Va, praying that all the Associations of North America should use their influence for a peaceful separation, seeing that secession was a fixed fact.
He remarked that to that end they were about to send two delegates to remind the Richmond people that a stubborn child was not to be allowed to abuse and maltreat its good old mother — the Union.

Rev. Mr. Curtis was called out. He re marked that the present aspect of things hardly verified the time when the sword should be beaten into the plough share, and it was strange, that amid the highest American civilization, there should be witnessed the present difficulties.

The Old World, too, was at fever heat.--France was concerned in Italy and the case of the sick man. Austria was almost ready to attack the possessions of Victor Emanuel.
Prussia and Denmark had their matters of dispute.
Russia also was anxious about Poland and the division of Turkey, with a future outlook to Indian possessions; and England by fleet and armies was striving to maintain her statu quo. In the New World, the United States were striving to cope with a direct rebellion and insurrection in their midst.

He believed with another speaker that the contest would be a long one, and most trying to our patriotism.
He was convinced the North would succeed in the end, and he hoped that success would never ensue until the South fairly begged for peace.

Dr. I. F. Hart was called upon.
He said, we have been privileged to listen to remarks this evening brimming over with overwhelming patriotism; but to him came the sad thought that, perhaps, we were soon to part with those who have labored and suffered with us, and whom we may never again behold in this life.
He was reminded of their presence and work in the mission prayer meetings and Sabbath schools, in the weekly prayer meetings of the Association, which, as members of the Church Committee, they had contributed a noble share in sustaining, and yet he was consoled in the fact that, by leaving, they will accomplish far more good than by remaining.
He would remind them, that the prayers of the Association would go with them, in the barrack or battle-field, and in return he hoped their prayers would ascend for the prosperity and spiritual welfare of the brethren left behind.
Thus might it be until by the mercies of a Divine Providence, they might be permitted to return to give an account of their stewardship.

Before the exercises were concluded, some of the volunteers upon leaving the room exclaimed, "Remember, don't disgrace them;" "Use them rightly;" carried away by the patriotic spirit of the occasion.
The audience, all standing, then sang "Home, sweet home." Benediction was pronounced by Rev. Mr. Curtis.

div3.head: Spies in Virginia.
div3.p:
We were much struck with the letter in Saturday's Dispatch, from our Fredericksburg correspondent.
That there are spies and informers all over Virginia, we cannot doubt.--Our people are too negligent in this matter; too apprehensive of making mistakes.
We had better err on the side of individual injustice than jeopard the public interests.
It can hurt nobody, even if suspected unjustly, to put them in confinement, and where they can do no harm.
One of the merciful rules of Christianity, like many other of its humane precepts, must be reversed in war, for in such a condition it is better that nine innocent should suffer than that one guilty should escape.

There is little danger, we apprehend, of innocent men suffering.
In times like these, innocent men can easily establish their innocence.
We are too credulous, too forbearing.
Our enemy is just the reverse.
He is hard hearted, unbelieving, inexorable.
But, thank Heaven, we are learning wisdom from experience, and we have at our head the great man of action of these times.
Since the days of George Washington we have had no such example of the right man in the right man in the right place as Jefferson Davis.

div3.head: Church contributions to the war.
div3.p:
The ministers of the Gospel throughout the South have been appealed to, to have collections taken up on Thanksgiving day in behalf of the cause in which the country is engaged, and upon which the people on that day are to invoke the favor of Heaven.
We think this appeal will be generally complied with, and we hope to see a liberal exhibition of patriotism in the contributions made on the impressive occasion.
We are informed that the proposition meets the cordial sanction of the Secretary of the Treasury, and doubt not that the contributions will be highly appreciated by the Southern Government.
Here is an occasion for all to put in according to their ability.
Here the widow's single mite may tell as well as the millionaire's many mites.
It is an occasion in which all will have an opportunity to give according to their means and feelings.

div3.head: The Virginia mountaineers.
div3.p:
The late report in the mountains that the enemy was marching upon Lewisburg had, at least, the good effect of showing the kind of reception they were likely to meet in such an attempt.
The mountaineers turned out like hornets from their nests, each man armed with the deadly mountain rifle and a butcher-knife.
With these weapons they stationed themselves in ambush, and in narrow passes, in companies of fifties and hundreds.--Old men, whose heads are whitened with the frosts of eighty winters, came armed, unwilling to give the arduous post to their sons.
An invading enemy would have a gay time in attempting to make their way over the Virginia mountains.

div3.head: The Zouaves of New Orleans.
div3.p:
A friend remarks to us that he thinks if the daguerreotypes of the French Zouave regiment now in this city could be taken and sent to Gen. Butler, he would immediately evacuate his present quarters.
Heaven help his Vermonters or Ellsworth's so-called Zouaves when these fierce-faced and genuine sons of Mars come after them!
The New York firemen will find a conflagration the like of which they never witnessed in their combustible city, and which they have no machinery for putting out.

div3.head: Clothing for soldiers.
div3.p: We are requested to state that the ladies of St. Peter's (Catholic) Cathedral will be happy to devote their services to making clothing for the soldiers, and that, for this purpose, or any other in which they can aid the brave defenders of their country, they request orders to be sent to the rooms of Mr. Jas. Purcell, corner of 14th and Pearl streets, at any time from 9 till 3 o'clock.

div3.head: Secretary Walker.
div3.p:
We are pleased to learn that the Hon. Mr. Walker, Secretary of War, is recovering from his recent sickness.
His official duties have been of the most arduous character, and have been discharged with an ability, zeal and fidelity, which entitle him to the gratitude of the Southern public.

div3.head: Designs of the enemy.
div3.p:
The enemy seem to be concentrating their forces at present with a view of marching upon Strasburg, and cutting off the communications with Harper's Ferry.
They can scarcely suppose that our military men are not alive to the importance of preventing such a movement.

div3.head: Louisa county.
div3.p:
Our gallant friend, Capt. Frobel, is meeting with fine success in Louisa county.
The people are subscribing money and horses most liberally to the guerilla force which the Captain is raising.
We learn that only one man has held back.

div3.head: The Wise brigade.
div3.p:
We understand that some of the finest companies of the Virginia forces have been transferred to the Wise Brigade.
The recruiting officers have the promise of ten thousand men.

div3.head: The Pawnee.
div3.p: --A letter from an officer in the Arkansas Regiment near Fredericksburg, published in the Lynchburg Republican, ventilates a report that in the late battle at Aquia Creek the Pawnee was struck with twelve shots, four of which passed through her, killing seventy-three men and wounding several others.

div3.head: Aquia Creek.
div3.p: --A letter from Aquia Creek (June 8) says:

q.p: "All is quiet here; there are no war vessels in sight."

div3.head: Bayonets.
div3.p:
--It is to be kept in mind that our battles are to be determined by the bayonet.
Few special shots are made in the excitement of a raging conflict, nor is mere marksmanship or evolution to have any decided effect upon the general result.
We must depend upon our hand-to- hand resources.
As the Zouaves and Chasseurs d'afrique on the field of Magenia and Solferino refused to accept their rations of powder and ball, but rushed forward and plunged their bayonets in the hearts of the enemy, so must we make up our minds to the fact not to stand off and fall in columns before the discharges of flying artillery and rattling musketry.
Close with your antagonists as rapidly as possible, and then, in the flashes of the bowie-knife and the bayonet, let God and your might be the arbiters of our fate.

div3.head: The blockade.
div3.p:
--We are beginning to fear that the Yankees will not maintain the strict blockade they have proclaimed.
First, they begin to require funds, and second, the recent manifestations of the English press all tend to indicate a sympathy for the South, which must soon find vent in a more substantia manner.
Cotton, or rather the want of it, is indirectly a casus belli;--and just so soon as the North attempts to prevent the departure of English bottoms from our ports with an article so needful to the welfare of millions of British artizans, just so soon will the imperious North find itself involved in difficulties beyond the circumvention of her shrewdest political machiavel.
Our statesmen have already initiated a policy concerning this staple which secures us all the income we desire.
The question, therefore, recurs whether the Federal Government will hesitate between the choice of a war with England, which would necessarily result from an interference with English commerce, and a blockade of our ports, which at best is only an annoyance to general commerce, and without effect upon the grand object for which it was designed.
Cotton is the sinews of war. It is also the muscle of the working classes of Great Britain.
They must have it or starve, and England will never permit them to rise in revolution as long as she can secure free "ingress and egress" of our ports.
The Northern papers are already shaking over the threatened interference, and the only fear now is that they may be induced to submit to the demand of England, and thus stave off that martial demonstration which is sure to follow from the present attitude of affairs between the two countries.

div3.head: General Floyd.
div3.p:
--A gentleman just arrived in our city from Lynchburg informs us that the troops collected at Wytheville, Abingdon, and other places through which he passed, are animated by a spirit of enthusiasm for the cause, and of devotion to the person of their distinguished leader, General Floyd, that of itself almost herald the victory that awaits our arms.
At Lynchburg, especially, was this spirit manifested.
There the very name of General Floyd operated like a talisman.--Lawyers, doctors, artizans and laborers are daily springing to arms, and glorying in the good fortune of having a crack at the invader under the banner of so popular a leader.
The Irish adopted citizens are especially enthusiastic, and rush to his standard with true Celtic devotion and fearless courage.
Should General Floyd's division.
be ordered to the Southwestern part of the State, which is probable from all that we can learn, he will teach our invaders a lesson that will strike dismay and terror into the dastardly hearts of the Washington Jesuit.

Our informant further tells us that all along the railroad line from Lynchburg to Knoxville, men, women and children greet our troops as they pass, and that on the whole route the flag of the oppressor is not to be seen, while our Southern banner floats from every house-top.

div3.head: Landing of Federal troops at White House Point.
div3.p: --Passengers by the Central train yesterday bring contradictory reports about the landing of Yankee troops at White House Point, on the Potomac; but the following, from the Lynchburg Republican, seems reliable:

Through a gentleman direct from Alexandria, a citizen of that place, we learn that about two thousand Federal troops have been landed at the White House, on the Virginia side of the Potomac, about seventeen miles below Alexandria, and about the same distance from Manassas Junction.
They intend fortifying themselves strongly at this point, and a much larger force is expected to be landed in a few days.

The bridges on the Orange Road, from Alexandria towards the Junction, are being rebuilt, and the road otherwise repaired, with the view of making use of the road; and it was generally believed that an advance movement of the troops from Alexandria, co-operating with those stationed at the White House, would be made in a few days.

div3.head: Clinton Rench.
div3.p:
--The Baltimore boys in this city have been aroused to a pitch of desperation by the announcement of the murder of the above named gentleman.
He was one of the most active members of Company F, of the Baltimore City Guard, beloved by all his comrades, brave as a lion, and a thorough-going Southerner.
He died while uttering his sentiments, and there is not a man in the Baltimore battalion who is not ready to-day to march to Williamsport, and at the point of the bayonet avenge his untimely end.

div3.head: The "Union" gun overboard.
div3.p:
--A monster gun called the "Union," cast at Pittsburg, and weighing upwards of fifty thousand pounds, fell overboard whilst being shipped at Baltimore for Fortress Monroe last Friday.
The water where the gun fell in was about six feet deep, but there was under it a soft mud, which was sounded to the depth of six feet more; and the gun that evening was about twelve feet below the surface of the water.

div3.head: The late General Garland.
div3.p:
--Brevet Brigadier General John Garland, who died in New York on the 6th instant, was in the 66th year of his age. Few officers of the United States Army have seen as much service as General Garland.
Entering the army from Virginia in the war of 1812, he served on the Indian frontier, afterwards in Florida, and led his command, the fourth infantry, in every battle fought in Mexico, save that of Buena Vista,

div3.head: Crops in Rockbridge.
div3.p: --A letter from Rockbridge county, Va., gives an encouraging account of the present condition of the crops in that section.

div3.head: A General Convention proposed.
div3.p: --The annexed petition, says the New York Journal of Commerce, has already received many thousand signatures in that city and vicinity: To the President of the United States:

Regarding you as the legal head of our Government, we respectfully, suggest, as the only remaining honorable position in your power by which the horrors of civil war may be averted and any hope of preserving the Union secured, that you adopt the policy of a General Convention, as suggested in your inaugural.
This course would prevent hostilities on the part of the South, and evince that fraternity had still a place in the hearts of the American people.

div3.head: American vessels under the British flag.
div3.p:
The Morrill tariff and the war are seriously affecting the commerce of New York.
The effect on American ship-owners is also disastrous.
The Journal of Commerce says:

q.p: Sales of American vessels to British subjects resident here continue to be frequent, and nearly all the commerce between the ports of the United States and those of Cuba, the West Indies, Central and South America and the Pacific coast, will probably soon be done under the British flag.

div3.head: Arrest.
div3.p: --A Rockingham county correspondent (June 7) says:

q.p: George Blakemore, charged with the murder of Jacob Rohn, of this county, and who had escaped the vigilance of our officers, was arrested a few days ago in the county of Highland and lodged in jail in this place last night.

div3.head: From Washington.
div3.p: --The Southern papers contain the following telegram from Washington, June 7:

It is believed that Lord Lyons' dispatches to his Government are unfavorable to the Lincolnites.
The Cabinet has been in session every day this week on foreign affairs, which, it is believed, are ominous of trouble.

div3.head: Arrest.
div3.p: --Winfield-Scott Anderson, arrested at the Relay House on a charge of furnishing aid and comfort to the Southern Confederacy, underwent an examination before the United States Commissioner in Baltimore on Friday, and was held in $4,000 for a further hearing.

The Frankfort (Ky.) Yeoman learns that Lieut. Col. George B. Crittenden, and all the other officers of the army from the Southern States stationed at Santa Fe, New Mexico, had resigned.
Colonel Crittenden is a son of Hon. John J. Crittenden, of Kentucky.

div3.head: Mayor's Court.
div3.p:
--The following cases were heard and determined by the Mayor yesterday: John B. Senot, resident of Byrd street, fighting on Sunday, beating his wife, making outrageous noises, and expressing the hope that Lincoln would come to Richmond and burn up all the houses.
Sent on for indictment on the various charges, save that of beating his wife, and committed in default of $380 bail.
Remanded for beating his wife until this morning.--Robert Luice, (or Lewis,) committed on the charge of suspicion of murder.
Defendant is suspected of having murdered a mulatto, named Mike Wright, in Anson county, N. C., on the 10th of February, 1860. He came into one of the military camps on Sunday, when he was taken in custody by parties conversant with the circumstances and handed over to the custody of the police.
It is said that he killed a man named Williams, at Cheraw, S. C., and served out a term of imprisonment for the offence.
It was after this that the people suspected him of killing Wright, and he left.
He came here as volunteer from Camden.
His case was continued for further inquiry to be made into it.--Ths. Hollen, drunk, disorderly, and flourishing an Allen's revolver, committed in default of surety for his good behavior.--Thomas B. Anthony, old and wiry-faced, with matted and dishevelled locks, arraigned for noisy manifestations on Broad street, Sunday.
Arrested by officer Seal after being reprimanded and promising to go home peacefully, which he did not do by a jug full.
Seal occupied twenty minutes in getting him stowed away.
His resistance was determined, but did not avail.
Required to give security; and failing, sent down.--Mary Moore and Teney Kidd, arrested for raising a disturbance of a continual character in a cellar inhabited by them.
A third party, named "corn juice," though not prominently brought forward, no doubt instigated the ladies in their doings against the peace of the neighborhood.
They wish to prove, and did prove, that they had been allowed the privilege of inhabiting the cellar; but the Mayor said that did not authorize them to make themselves nuisances.
Required to give security, and failed.--Mrs. Martha West had Edward Hill up for uttering threats against her. Two witnesses swore exactly the reverse of each other about the matter, and the Mayor continued the case until to-day.--Daniel Johnson, a person with sunburnt face and heavy beard, who said he was partly raised in Kentucky and partly in Canada, and had just arrived from New York with a letter from General Cocke to Governor Letcher, the latter of whom told him to circulate around as he pleased, was placed in durance till his Excellency could be called on Austin Gibbons, arrested for using incendiary language, was committed.
Gibbons said he was drunk.
The Mayor told him, "out of the abundance of the heart the mouth speaketh," and he should have to send him, at least for a time, where the police cease from troubling and the wicked are at rest.
Committed indefinitely.--Herignes Hill, assaulting Dominick McDonough, examined and acquitted.--Degrassy Drumwright, discharged on condition that he leave the city in twenty-four hours and never return.
Condition accepted.--Jas. R. Lawrence, a person ostensibly a painter's clerk, but privately fond of nippers and correspondence with burglars, and "putting" up jobs for the same, committed as a person of evil name and fame — a name to which he is eminently entitled, judging from the revelations made at the Mayor's Court.--Margaret Lynch, a dissolute and abandoned female, said to be white, was committed for associating with negroes.
A tread-mill would operate admirably on such disgusting figments of humanity as this Miss Lynch.
A little of the law of the old judge, her progenitor, would not do her much hurt.--Frederick Lieeke was committed in default of surety for general drunkenness.
He hoped to escape punishment by giving the police a false name, but the scheme did not work well.

div3.head: Domestic Traitors.
div3.p:
--The latest European advices represent John C. Fremont as in the act of hastily leaving Paris for this country, where he had expressed a desire to raise a mob of twenty thousand congenial ruffians, for a crusade against the place of his nativity.
If the adventurer was in Paris, and getting along finely in practising on the credulity of the French bankers, by false representations respecting his Mariposa estate, as Black Republican authorities represent him to have been, he ought to have worked the mine to the bed rock.
It will pay more to the "pan" to work those "diggings" than any crusade he could originate and set against the South.--Impartial history, when written, will hold up to the indignant gaze of posterity no two more traitorous and deep-dyed villains than this same Fremont and Gen. Scott, natives though they be of the sunny South.
It will be written down that neither they nor their followers were moved by motives of honor or impulses of patriotism.
With these two leaders of the borders now preparing to subjugate the South, disappointed ambition and a thirst for revenge is the leading motive — with their asinine followers it is only the pirate's and freebooter's desire for plunder.
Both Fremont and Scott will have the infamous distinction of being fratricides, and leaders of thieves, oppressors and common cut-throats.--Granny Scott, who is represented to be in his dotage, was, unluckily for the honor of the Old Dominion, born on her soil, by one of those freaks of nature which sometimes gives to a comely mother a deformed child.
He is her first traitor offering of any magnitude.--Fremont, the product of a hason between the young wife of old Col. Pryor and a French dancing master, would have been born in Richmond, in the house at present occupied by H. W. Fry, Esq., next to the City Hall, had not an untimely discovery of the little intimacy alluded to above caused the compulsory absence of Mrs. Pryor and her inamorata from Richmond.
Fremont first saw the light of day in Charleston, S. C. Whether goaded by the thoughts of his ignoble birth, or what other motive we know not, he has been engaged all his life in desperate enterprises.
From the time he stole Jessie Benton down to this, he has been trying some new scheme to place his name on the roll of fame.
He has the credit of being the first one who ever essayed with any success to marshal the motley hordes of abolitionism in a regular war (at the ballot-box) against the South and its integrity.
He did not succeed then, nor do we imagine he will now, though he proposes to substitute bullets for ballots.

In the Presidential campaign in which he was the standard-bearer of the enemies of the South, it was regarded as a remarkable fact, even in the excitement which had grown up on the sectional question which then bade fair to dismember the Confederacy, and which has since accomplished the act, that a man who derived his education and early subsistence from the charity of Southern ladies should be selected to marshal the opposition to Southern rights and interests.
Surprise was expressed that a man who was indebted to South Carolina gentlemen for early assistance in life, should be so far forgetful of ordinary gratitude and feeling as to offer himself as a leader in a crusade against the dearest rights of his benefactors.
The latter marvelled much that one who had passed his early years in the South, and in the educated community of Charleston, should be so lost to all early associations.
In contrasting his present position with that formerly occupied by him, they will still find cause for surprise and indignation.
In early life the talents of Fremont were nurtured by gentle hands; in approaching manhood he was upheld by generous and patriotic men; and in the encouragement of his genius he was upheld by South Carolina, who (like Virginia to Scott) presented him a sword, which is now to be drawn in the hope of sheathing it in the giver's bosom.
Like Judas, both Scott and Fremont have been seduced and sold themselves for a price.
If they do not, like their great prototype, "let out their bowels" from very shame at their own abasement, we trust that some of the stalwart soldiers of the Southern Confederacy may be enabled to do the job for them in an effectual if not brilliant manner.

div3.head: Tent cloth.
div3.p:
--We are informed by the Quartermaster in charge of the tent department that the difficulty about obtaining tents arises from an inadequate supply of tent cloth.
All that could be obtained has been bought, and there is no supply of cloth in this market sufficient to turn out the quantity desired.
Arrangements have been made to furnish large quantities of tents from the South, and it is hoped that all of the troops will soon be supplied.
Every effort has heretofore been made, and if troops have suffered they must blame Lincoln's blockade, which has cut off the supply of cloth, and not the Quartermaster's Department.

div3.head: Death of the State Armorer.
div3.p:
--The Dispatch received on Sunday an intimation of the death of A. M. Ball, Esq., the former Superintendent of the Armory at Harper's Ferry.
It was, however, on a subject which did not admit of a wrong announcement, and being withal couched in very ambiguous terms, it was deemed better not to give currency to it. It appears, however, that Mr. Ball is dead.
He reached Harper's Ferry, from this city, last Thursday evening, and shortly after retired, to all appearances, in his usual health; but on going to his room the next morning he was found dead on his couch.
His death is ascribed to apoplexy.
The loss of such a man at the present juncture is to be regretted on many accounts.
While the Harper's Ferry Armory was owned by the late United States, and Mr. Ball was Superintendent thereof, he acquired a high reputation for mechanical skill.
He made many valuable improvements in machinery for the manufacture of fire-arms.
Mr. B. was also distinguished for gentlemanly bearing, and was much esteemed by a large circle of friends.

We call attention to the following paper which was left at this office, as we have intimated, on Sunday.
There is a great reason why its recommendations should be attended to:

q.p:
"A subscription has been opened at the Exchange Hotel for the relief of the widow and four children of our lamented friend, Master Armorer at Harper's Ferry, A. M. Ball, of Virginia, who has left his wife and four children, all of Virginia, in this city penniless to mourn his loss.
This untimely death will be greatly lamented by all who know him, particularly this Southern Confederacy, who required his eminent aid and skill of his profession.
Come one, come all, to their relief."

div3.p: Papers favorable to the widow and orphans will please copy.

div3.head: A Nut for A. Lincoln.
div3.p:
--In the Rev. Mr. Nolley's congregation, (colored,) on Sunday afternoon last, a colored man walked into the church, clad in military costume.
After a few moments of secret devotion, he sent to the minister a paper, which proved to be a certificate from the Rev. Mr. Keener, Presiding Elder of the New Orleans District, stating that the bearer was an acceptable member of the M. E. Church South, in the city of New Oorleans--"a pious and a reliable man." At the close of his discourse, Mr. Nolley invited him to say a few words to the congregation.
He readily consented.
Among other things, he stated that he was connected with the "Washington Artillery," from the city of New Orleans, who had come here to resist the enemies of their country.
He begged an interest in the prayers of the congregation in his own behalf, and in behalf of his company: that, if they should be called into the field of battle, they might be "protected, and gain the victory over their enemies." At the close of his remarks, he offered up a prayer in the same strain.
He prayed fervently for his master and mistress in the city of New Orleans.
He prayed for his company of soldiers — that they might "get the victory." I need not say that the minister and whole congregation responded hearty "amens" to these petitions.
This man is a type of the vast majority of the colored people in all the Southern States.
They will be true to their masters and true to their country.
Let A. Lincoln and his horde of Abolitionists arm themselves well against the prayers and other efforts, even of the colored population of the South.

div3.head: Evening parades.
div3.p:
--Just now the most interesting localities in our vicinity are camps, and especially so in the latter part of the day, when the volunteers assemble upon their evening parades.
On these occasions the President is frequently present and reviews the forces.--This was the case yesterday afternoon at Howard's Grove, where are encamped the Zouaves, the Washington Artillery, of New Orleans, a Regiment of Georgians, and other corps whose names do not occur to mind.
Probably not less than three thousand ladies and gentlemen were present on foot and in vehicles, and between the gay attires and handsome faces of the women, the various-colored uniforms of the soldiers, the flashing bayonets, the martial tramp of the men, and the inspiring music of the band, the scene was invested with a life and beauty that kept out of mind the solemn object of all this demonstration.

The President was on horseback, accompanied by Gov. Letcher and an aid. Hon. Pierre Soule, of Louisiana, and Ex-Senator Wigfall, of Texas, also mounted, were likewise upon the field, interested observers of passing events.

In all the camps, preparations for active service are constantly going on. Men are daily drilling, inuring themselves to the hardships hereafter to be encountered, and learning those lessons of the soldier which is to enable them when in the presence of the enemy to combine their brave determination with the most effective mode of displaying it in the defence of their rights, their homes and firesides.

div3.head: Percussion cap machine.
div3.p:
--We are gratified to announce the completion of this ingenious, and, at the present time, very important piece of mechanism, and we are now independent, so far as the manufacture of percussion caps is concerned.
We witnessed the operation of it yesterday, and found that it turned out caps as expeditiously, and as well, as the famous Government machine exhibited at the Mechanics' Institute some years ago. It is, moreover, handsomely finished, and not likely to wear out by constant usage.
The caps, which it turns out at the rate of 20,000 a day, are as good as any we ever used.
The inventors and makers of this machine are Messrs. W. & C. Bradley, whose establishment across the river has heretofore produced some as fine and ingenious work as any manufactory in the country.
They are certainly entitled to the thanks of the whole South for what they have accomplished in this instance.

Virginians do not begin to appreciate the fact that we are at war. If so, a thousand carcasses of the enemy would by this time have told the tale.
We have been preaching about guerillas.
Where are they?
On paper.
Jackson, the brother of the Alexandria martyr, is the only one of whom we have a bloody record.
He is doing his duty like a man. Some nineteen are said to have already fallen under his rifle, and not a night passes that he is not skirting among the bushes, and picking off the outposts of the enemy.
Had every man done as well, Virginia soil would not be traversed with the boldness and impunity which characterizes its present invaders.
When one can inspire terror, what may not a hundred or a thousand do. If there are guerillas, let them be no longer a myth.
Go to work.
Let bullets take the place of words.

Most of the old Officers of either the Navy or Army of the United States, who were entitled to any consideration at the hands of their fellow-countrymen as officers and gentlemen, are now doing yeomen's service in the cause of the Southern Confederacy.
Among the Virginians entitled to an honorable mention, is Lieut. John R. Eggleston, who resigned from the steamer Wyandotte the day previous to that on which Fort Pickens was reinforced.--He is a native of Amelia county, Va., but removed to Mississippi when a youth and was appointed a midshipman from that State.
Up to the time of his resignation he had been in service for many years in the Pacific and Atlantic, and he is now engaged in a very important service for the Confederate States, which will ere long gratify and astonish his friends.

div3.head: Ups and Downs of life.
div3.p:
--In the "Volunteer Southrons," recently arrived from Vicksburg, Mississippi, is a gentleman who a number of years ago was the competitor of his Excellency Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States, for the office of State representative, and beat him. One who still maintains his position as an honorable citizen of his State, now a volunteer under the Confederate flag of the South; the other has been elevated to the high position of the Chief Magistrate of our country, and is wielding the helm of the nation.
Such is life.
No man can tell what the revolution of the wheel of fortune has in store for him; and when we least expect, we may drop into spheres of action which has never intruded within the scope of our calculations.

div3.head: Printers' ink.
div3.p:
--Messrs. Taylor & Hargrove, who not long since established a printing ink manufactory at the corner of Adams and Leigh streets, in this city, have gotten the same in full operation, and are daily turning out fine specimens of blue, green, red and black printing ink. When the Yankees initiated the present difficulties, they feverishly imagined that the want of the above article would necessarily stop all the "rebel" presses between Maryland and the Rio Grande.
They will ere long find out they have been as much mistaken in all their other calculations as in this.

div3.head: Hustings Court.
div3.p: --The monthly term of this tribunal commenced yesterday, when the following business was transacted--Alderman Sanxay presiding:

St. Geo. Peachy's account for holding inquests from 14th January, 1861, to 27th April, 1861, was certified and ordered to be paid.--Also, an account of the visitors to the several Tobacco Warehouses of this city.
The certificate of the election of Wm. Taylor as Alderman, was returned to the Court and filed.
Nolle prosequis were entered in the case of Beverly Bloomer and Geo. Bloomer, charged with felony, and in the case of Caroline Cart and Caroline Cates, presented for misdemeanor.
The Sergeant was directed to summon fifteen petty jurymen to-day to try misdemeanor cases.

Mr. James Thomas, Jr., of this city, on the 7th of June, presented a fine box of chewing tobacco to the members of Company "F, " now stationed at Aquia Creek; also, a barrel of superb smoking tobacco.
This gentleman, as well as others, has shown his appreciation of the services to be rendered by the soldiers, by first sending them to the field properly equipped and then comforting them after their arrival.
The "F" boys say they properly appreciate the kindness of Mr. T. A. resolution of thanks to him was adopted at a meeting of the company held a few nights since.

div3.head: Returned home.
div3.p:
--The R. L. I. Blues, who have been on duty for several weeks past in the vicinity of Aquia Creek and the enemy's cruisers, having been ordered back to this post, returned by the Fredericksburg route yesterday, under the gallant Capt., O. J. Wise.
The Blues looked "none the worse for wear" on account of their exposure on the tented field.
We believe they were marched away at such short notice that they never yet have been mustered regularly into service.
If so, that formality will now be complied with.

div3.head: A dangerous Element,
div3.p:
--Whilst we do not desire or intend to urge war on females, we must in candor and as a matter of duty and safety say, that females who express sentiments disloyal to the Southern Confederacy should be compelled to leave the same, and seek refuge in a Northern clime more congenial to their feelings and sentiments.
Their sojourn among us may be attended with serious injury to our cause.
If their feelings affiliate with Lincoln and his horde, they will impart information detrimental to the South Let the police see to them.

div3.head: Col. Hampton's Legion, S. C.
div3.p:
--This fine command is rapidly organizing and will soon be ready to take the field.
It consists of six companies of infantry, four of light dragoons, and one flying artillery--in all, 1,000 men. The accomplished Adjutant of this command, Lieut. Theodore Gailliard Barker, is now in this city on business connected with the Legion.

div3.head: Sickness.
div3.p:
--Medical men report considerable sickness in Richmond, owing to sundry sudden changes recently in the weather.
People cannot be too careful.
Disease of the bowels and bad colds, which grow to something worse very soon, are remarkably sure to remove the surplus population who may stand in their way.

Mr. Finch, who was blown up a few days since by the explosion of a lot of fulminating powder, at his house, on Clay street, is at the hospital, receiving all the attention and kindness needed by one in his situation.
The physicians cannot yet determine whether he will over regain the sight of either of his eyes.

In yesterday's Dispatch we said that the Louisiana Cadets had brought along with them the fine Newfoundland dog that escaped from the dirty followers of Old Abe, now cooped up in Fort Pickens.
The company who have the dog in charge are the "Orleans Cadets," Lieut, H. F. Bond commanding.

div3.head: Attention, Militia.
div3.p:
--Capt. Jos. J. White's company of Virginia Militia is called upon, by an advertisement in our columns this morning, to attend parade on Wednesday evening next.
As an election of 1st and 2d Lieutenants is to take place, a full turn-out is desirable, in order to secure good officers.

div3.head: [Communicated.]

opener.salute:
To the Rev. Cornelius Walker, D. D., Rector Christ Church, Alexandria:
Sir:

div3.p: --It is stated in the journals of the day, that on a certain Sunday recently, you preached as usual in your church, assisted by Rev. Mr. Myers, Chaplain of the Michigan Regiment.

Now, as this was not a private, but a public transaction, and as the Southern public has a vital interest in a precedent involving grave consequences, I will take the liberty to make the following inquiry and inference.--As the Ritual of your Church prescribes a prayer for "the President and all others in authority," and as your Rev. Assistant on this occasion was an officer, commissioned and paid, in the forces now holding Alexandria as a conquered city, I would respectfully ask, for what "President " and for what "authorities" did that gentleman pray?
If for your President, and your authorities, then he is a traitor to the cause in which he is enlisted; but if he prayed for his President, and his authorities, then he is not a traitor, but some one else is.

div3.head: Brilliant achievement — the first Yankee victory
div3.p: --A House Bombarded and a Negro Dislodged.
The Norfolk Day Book, of Saturday, gives the following account of an achievement of the enemy:

We learn that one of the Federal steamers supposed to be the Quaker City, yesterday fired-about twenty shot and shell into a private dwelling-house near Cape Henry Beach, completely demolishing the entire structure The property, we understand, belongs to David Corprew, Esq., and is within a mile and a half of Lynnhaven Bay.
It had been used as a headquarters for the Princess Anne Cavalry, but it was at that time vacant, no one being on the premises except an old negro man, who was in the yard, and on the first shot striking the house he tumbled over with fright, but on recovering, picked himself up and crawled away on his hands and knees.

div3.head: Naval intelligence.
div3.p: --A correspondent of the Petersburg Express writes from Norfolk.

The Merrimac has been gotten up and repairs are to be made on her forthwith.
The Lincolnites burned this noble frigate down to the copper.
Two or three months, however, will suffice to make her whole again.
Three or four steamers are being fitted out at the Navy-Yard, after the regular man-of war style, to cruise in-the sounds of North Carolina, and to run out to sea and pick up the merchant marine of the North.
This will be glorious fun, and the gallant officers who command these vessels will doubtless reap a rich harvest from the Yankee Doodles.
--We find the following paragraph in the Baltimore Exchange of Thursday last:

Yesterday morning there arrived from Washington fifty-six of the Garibaldian regiment which passed through our city a few days since.
These men state that the regiment is thoroughly disorganized, and the men, for the most part, will return to their homes.
When it was proposed to enlist them for three years they refused to comply, and the Government threatened to disband the regiment unless they entered the service for three years. The threat did not have the desired effect, and the regiment will certainly disband.
Those who have arrived here state that they have been cheated and deceived from the time they tendered their services until they left the regiment, and under no circumstances will they fight to sustain the Government.

div3.head: Col. R. A. Stewart, the fighting parson, in the field
div3.p:
--We understand that Col. Stewart is now raising a Flying Artillery company, to be called the Beauregard Battery.--It will be a crack company, our informant says, and the parson will fight sure.
We hope Col. Stewart, who has the guns of his command, will receive every other assistance he may require to fit his company out for the field of war as soon as possible.
We recommend him as a bold, fearless and capable officer, and one who has been under fire.--N. O. Delta.

Perilous Passage of the Maid of the Mist. The steamer Maid of the Mist passed down through the rapids at Niagara Falls on the afternoon of the 6th inst., under the suspension bridge, with two men in charge.
She lost her smoke-stack below the bridge, but other wise is apparently safe.
There was great excitement at the time.

div3.head: More Plundering
div3.p:
--Last week a small vessel, loaded with provisions, and belonging to Captain Adams, in attempting to come to market, from Smithfield, was captured by the Yankees.
We learn there were 4,000 pounds of bacon on board.--Norfolk Argus.
The 19th Regiment of New York volunteers, and the 3d Regiment of Maine volunteers, passed through Baltimore on Friday last.
